qas.question: What was the National Military Establishment renamed in 1949?
How many subordinate divisions did the National Military Establishment contain?
What does the US Navy's responsibilities include?

answers.text: sea-based operations from aircraft carriers and amphibious aircraft

qas.question: Who is in charge of closed air support of infantry operations?
What American broke the sound barrier in 1947?

context: The act created the National Military Establishment (renamed <a0_0>Department of Defense<a0_0/> in 1949), which was composed of <a1_0>three<a1_0/> subordinate Military Departments, namely the Department of the Army, the Department of the Navy, and the newly created Department of the Air Force. Prior to 1947, the responsibility for military aviation was shared between the Army (for land-based operations), the Navy (for <a2_0>sea-based operations from aircraft carriers and amphibious aircraft<a2_0/>), and the <a3_0>Marine Corps<a3_0/> (for close air support of infantry operations). The 1940s proved to be important in other ways as well. In 1947, <a4_0>Captain Chuck Yeager<a4_0/> broke the sound barrier in his X-1 rocket-powered aircraft, beginning a new era of aeronautics in America.
